questions.text: Trombiculid mites are the vectors for the transmission of which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Trombiculid mites are the vectors for the transmission of scrub typhus.

Transovarial transmission refers to passing on the disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod. Orientia tsutsugamushi is maintained by transovarial transmission in trombiculid mites. Transovarian transmission is also seen in Rickettsia rickettsii, Rickettsia conorii, and Rickettsia akari.

The image below shows a trombiculid mite.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a neutralization test?
questions.solution:
Wassermann test is an example of a complement fixation test, not a neutralization test.

Wassermann test is a non-specific test for the diagnosis of syphilis. An antigen combines with its (specific) antibody in the presence of complement, and the antigen-antibody complex adsorbs the complement. This reaction is not visible and requires the use of an indicator (sheep erythrocytes and the specific anti-erythrocyte antibody).

Examples of neutralization tests include

  • Virus neutralization tests: Neutralization of viruses by antibodies.
    • Plaque inhibition test for neutralization of bacteriophages
  • Toxin neutralization tests: Bacterial exotoxins neutralization by antibodies
    • Nagler reaction: done for the detection of alpha toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens
    • Schick test: Neutralization of diphtheria toxin by circulating antitoxin
    • Anti-streptolysin O test: Neutralization of streptococcal O hemolysin produced by beta-hemolytic streptococci.

questions.text: A 60-year-old homeless and malnourished man was admitted to the hospital with a high grade fever and night sweats. He tested positive for HIV on admission. He also complained of a productive cough, with small amounts of thick, purulent sputum. He mentions that he has reduced appetite and has lost weight. He is a chronic alcoholic and smoker. His sputum sample was collected and sent for microscopy and culture. Staining and microscopy showed the following image. How does the person get infected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing pneumonia in a HIV-positive patient and microscopy showing modified acid-fast positive and branching, filamentous rods is suggestive of Nocardia asteroides. Transmission is thought to be through inhalation of contaminated soil.

Nocardia are gram-positive strict aerobes found particularly in the soil and are found to produce lung infections mostly in the immunocompromised.

Nocardia is frequently found in the soil and infection is exogenous. Person-to-person transmission does not occur. It is found worldwide in soil and infection can occur in animals as well.

They are gram-positive and are also positive in Kinyoun's acid-fast staining technique.

Clinical manifestations:

Cutaneous infections may lead to local abscesses, cellulitis, or lymphocutaneous lesions

Pleuropulmonary nocardiosis usually manifests as pneumonia, lung abscess, or other lesions resembling tuberculosis. Symptoms may include fever, night sweats, weight loss, chest pain, cough with or without sputum production, and shortness of breath.

Hematogenous spread from the lung is most frequently to the brain. Other common sites include skin, kidneys, bones, muscles, and eyes, but almost any organ can be involved. Cutaneous infection may lead to local abscesses, cellulitis, lymphocutaneous lesions or actinomycotic mycetoma.

Treatment - Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Cotrimoxazole) is the drug of choice.

Other options :

Close differentials to Nocardia include

  • Actinomyces species that causes Actinomycosis is endogenous in human beings. They are gram-positive filamentous bacteria similar to Nocardia but are not acid-fast positive.
  • Nocardia mimics tuberculosis in clinical presentation, but tuberculosis is transmitted by an infected person. 
  • Nocardia species infect animals but transmission from animals to human beings does not take place.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text:
Match the respective organisms with their periodicity.
1. Wuchereria bancrofti a. Diurnal
2. Loa loa b. Nocturnal
3. Onchocerca volvulus c. Nonperiodic
4.  Brugia malayi
questions.solution:
Correct match of periodicity is:

1. Wuchereria bancrofti b. Nocturnal 
2. Loa loa a. Diurnal
3. Onchocerca volvulus c. Nonperiodic
4.  Brugia malayi b. Nocturnal

The microfilariae are found in large numbers in the peripheral blood during specific times of the day, depending on the blood-feeding habits of their insect vector. This is known as periodicity. Filarial worms can exhibit nocturnal, diurnal periodicity, or no periodicity at all.

  • Nocturnal periodicity: When the largest number of microfilariae are present in the blood at night. Eg- Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, Brugia timori
  • Diurnal periodicity: When the largest number of microfilariae occur in blood during the day. Eg- Loa loa
  • Nonperiodic: When the number of microfilariae maintains a constant level during the day and night. Eg- Onchocerca volvulus

questions.text: At what temperature does Listeria show the following type of motility?
questions.solution:
Listeria shows slow tumbling motility when grown at 25 °C. 

Interestingly, Listeria is nonmotile at 37°C because the peritrichous flagella are produced by the bacillus optimally between 20°C and 30°C. This is known as differential motility as the motility pattern changes with a change in temperature. 

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus. It can survive at refrigerator temperatures (4°C), under conditions of low pH and high salt. So it is able to overcome food preservation and safety barriers, making it an important foodborne pathogen. The virulence factor produced by Listeria is called listeriolysin O. This helps the bacteria to escape and causes septicemia. They are catalase-positive, will not produce H2S, and shows beta hemolysis. This helps to differentiate Listeria from other gram-positive bacilli.

L. monocytogenes enters the body after ingestion of contaminated foods such as refrigerated milk, cheese, fruit, or vegetables. Healthy persons exposed to L. monocytogenes in food may develop mild, self-limiting febrile gastroenteritis lasting 1–3 days. This develops after an incubation period of 6–48 hours. Symptoms include fever, chills, headache, myalgias, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Intra-uterine infection of the fetus results in neonatal sepsis, pustular lesions, and granulomas in multiple organs (granulomatosis infantiseptica). The late-onset syndrome causes meningitis in infants between birth and the third week of life.

The PALCAM agar is used to isolate Listeria monocytogenes. They show a grey-green with a black sunken center and a black halo on a cherry-red background. Stool culture is done in cold enrichment media.

It can be treated with ampicillin, cotrimoxazole, and gentamicin.

Please note that Listeria show a characteristic slow-tumbling motility. The GIF in the question has been sped up for illustrative purposes.

questions.text:
The binding groove and effector cells associated with HLA class 1 molecules are:

HLA : Human Leukocyte Antigen

choices.text: Beta I and Alpha I, CD4 T cells
Beta II and Alpha I, CD4 T cells
Alpha I and Alpha II, CD8 T cells
Alpha II and Beta II, CD8 T cells

questions.solution:
The binding groove associated with human leukocyte antigen I (HLA I) is between its alpha 1 and alpha 2 domains, and the effector cells involved are CD8 T cells.

The human major histocompatibility complex (MHC) is called the HLA complex. MHC is a cluster of genes whose products are responsible for antigen presentation to T cells, transplant rejection, etc.

HLA complex of genes is present on the short arm of chromosome 6. It consists of three separate clusters of genes, labeled as class I, II, and III.

HLA class I molecules are present on all nucleated cells. They consist of a heavy peptide chain called the alpha chain that is linked to β-2 microglobulin, which is called the beta chain. The alpha chain further consists of three domains called alpha 1, 2 and 3 that protrude from the cell membrane, as shown in the image below.

There exists a groove between the alpha 1 and alpha 2 domains, where small peptides formed subsequent to protein antigens being processed by macrophages or dendritic cells, bind for presentation to CD8 T cells.

Following this, the CD8 cytotoxic killer cell destroys the target cell. However, the T cell can recognise the antigen only when presented as a complex with the MHC class I molecule and this is called MHC restriction.

HLA class I antigens are involved in graft rejections and cell-mediated cytolysis and are also components of hormone receptors.

HLA class II molecules are present on macrophages, dendritic cells, activated T cells and B cells. They too consist of an alpha and beta chain, each having a proximal and distal domain, as shown in the image below.

The antigen-binding site comprises the two distal domains, which are alpha 1 and beta 1 domains. Antigens are bound for recognition by CD4 T cells. They are principally involved in graft-versus-host-disease and mixed leukocyte reactions.

HLA class III molecules include complement components linked to the formation of C3 convertases, heat shock proteins and tumour necrosis factors.

 

Related Pearl: MHC Classes I and II

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Expressed on all nucleated cells (except sperms) and platelets

Expressed on antigen-presenting cells: macrophages, B lymphocytes, dendritic cells

Consist of a polymorphic α, heavy-chain, linked non-covalently to β2-microglobulin

Heterodimer consisting of non-covalently associated α and β chains, both of which are polymorphic.

α chains are encoded by three genes- HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C

Encoded by HLA-D, with subregions: HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR.

Display antigenic peptides that are derived from viral and tumor proteins

Present antigens that are internalized into vesicles, and derived from extracellular microbes 

Class I complexes are recognized by CD8+ T cells

 

Class II complexes are recognized by CD4+ T cells

Endogenous peptide is the type of antigen presented to CD8+ T cells

 Exogenous antigen is the type of antigen presented to CD4+ T cells 

Presents antigen via the cytosolic pathway

 Presents antigen via the endocytic pathway 

Antigen binding site is present between α1/α2 groove

 Antigen binding site is present between α1/β1 groove 

α3 binds to CD8 molecules on cytotoxic T cells

 β2 binds to CD4 on helper T cells

questions.text: A diabetic patient after sustaining an abrasion wound while working in the field, presented with acute pneumonia with upper lobe infiltrates. Microscopy of the sample from the exudate showed gram-negative bacilli with typical bipolar staining with Wright’s stain,  prompting suspicion of Melioidosis. Which of the following is the best-suited culture medium to grow this organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the microscopic finding of gram-negative bacilli with a typical bipolar staining with Wright's stain is characteristic of melioidosis, caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei. Ashdown medium is selective for B. pseudomallei.

Melioidosis is also known as Whitmore's disease. It is an infection acquired by the contamination of abrasion wounds with soil and water containing the bacilli. Patients with underlying diseases like diabetes mellitus have an increased risk of acquiring the infection.

Clinically, melioidosis presents in two forms.

  • Acute - It causes acute pneumonia with upper lobe infiltrates or severe necrotizing disease. It can also mimic tuberculosis with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. It may lead to septicemia. Acute cases have a high case-fatality rate. 
  • Chronic - It can lead to the development of multiple caseous or suppurative foci, with skin and subcutaneous abscesses. These can lead to lymphangitis and lymphadenopathy. It may involve bones and other internal organs.

On microscopy, small, irregularly staining, gram-negative bacilli can be demonstrated for diagnosis. Methylene blue stain/ Wright's stain shows a typical bipolar safety pin appearance. ELISA for IgM and IgG antibody, indirect hemagglutination can be also used for diagnosis. Ashdown medium is a culture selective for B. pseudomallei.

The image below shows dry purple wrinkled colonies of B. pseudomallei cultured in Ashdown medium.

The image below shows gram-negative bacilli with a typical bipolar safety-pin appearance.

Treatment is divided into two stages: an intensive phase of 2 weeks of therapy with ceftazidime (drug of choice) or a carbapenem, followed by 12 weeks of oral cotrimoxazole to eradicate the organism and prevent relapse.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady presented with itchy vaginal discharge. Microscopic examination revealed organisms as shown. Which of the following is true regarding the infection?

choices.text: The organism shows jerky motility with its 2 flagella
Presents as fishy odor and curdy precipitate
Green kit is used for syndromic treatment

questions.solution:
The above scenario of a patient with itchy vaginal discharge with the presence of flagellated trophozoites on microscopy indicated a diagnosis of trichomonas vaginalis. Green kit containing secnidazole is used for the syndrome treatment of trichomonas vaginalis.

Trichomonas is transmitted from person to person. Trophozoites are infective forms. They exhibit jerky motility by means of 5 flagella. It classically causes petechial hemorrhage and mucosal capillary dilatation giving a 'strawberry cervix' appearance.

Diagnosis can be established by a wet mount smear of vaginal discharge. In doubtful cases, culture can be done to establish the diagnosis.Treatment of trichomonas can be done with a Tablet Metronidazole or tinidazole 2gm single dose or secnidazole 1gm daily for 2 days. Partner treatment is required when symptomatic and sexual contact with an infected partner should be avoided.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text:
A diabetic patient presents with an ear infection. After a detailed examination, he was diagnosed to have malignant otitis externa. The culture showed swarming motility, and the oxidase test was positive. Which of the following is not a characteristic of the causative organism?
  1. It is lactose fermenting in nature.
  2. It can grow in cetrimide selective medium.
  3. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyomelanin.
  4. It is an obligate anaerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of slime layer.
  5. It is a common etiological agent associated with chronic airway infection in patients with cystic fibrosis.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and positivity in the oxidase test and swarming are suggestive of infection by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is non-lactose fermenting in nature (Statement 1). They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin. Pyomelanin is a brown pigment produced by P.aeruginosa (Statement 3). It is an obligate aerobe(not an anaerobe) that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of slime layer (Statement 4).

P. aeruginosa is the most common cause of malignant otitis externa in diabetic persons. It is an obligate aerobe, gram-negative, catalase-positive, and oxidase-positive bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown). 

The GIF below shows the swarming motility seen in Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Pathogenesis - It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer. Breach in primary body defenses as in burns predisposes to Pseudomonas infection.

Clinical features - It is characterized by blue-green pus. Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum 

Cystic fibrosis is a condition, associated with thick inspissated mucus and impaired mucociliary clearance. Due to these factors, P. aeruginosa can cause chronic infection/colonization of the respiratory tract in patients with Cystic fibrosis (Statement 5). P.aeruginosa causing lung infection in cystic fibrosis patients is associated with biofilm formation. This biofilm provides a hypoxic environment and thereby protects it against antimicrobial agents.

It is notorious for being resistant to antimicrobials and antiseptics and hence is a frequent contaminant in hospital samples. Repeated isolation and associated clinical features should prompt the diagnosis of Pseudomonas. It can even grow in Dettol or cetrimide selective medium (Statement 2).

Diagnosis - It grows well on most media and pigment production makes its identification easy. Pseudomonas grows well on ordinary media, forms non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey medium, and are hemolytic on blood agar. Species identification is made possible by biochemical tests - arginine hydrolysis and oxidase reaction. Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth in a nutrient agar showing green-colored colonies is shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Oxygen Requirements of Bacteria

questions.text: A  female patient presented to the OPD with a history of progressive breathlessness and cough for 3 months. A chest X-ray showed a cavitary lesion in the lower lobe of the right lung. A wedge resection of the lung was done and the histopathology image is given below. Which of the following skin tests can be used to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological slide showing protoscolex and brood capsule are suggestive of hydatid disease of the lung caused by Echinococcus granulosus. It can be diagnosed by Casoni’s test.

The below image shows the histology of the hydatid cyst of the lung.

The hydatid cyst wall consists of 3 layers:

  • Pericyst- the outer dense fibrous capsule that is formed as a result of host inflammatory response.
  • Ectocyst- the intermediate layer consisting of acellular, chitinous, laminated hyaline material.
  • Endocyst- the inner germinal layer that is cellular and consists of a number of nuclei embedded in protoplasmic mass and is extremely thin. It is the vital layer of the cyst and it is the site of asexual reproduction giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.

Hydatid disease most commonly occurs in the liver, the second most common being the lungs. The clinical features of hydatid disease of the lung include breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, and even pneumothorax. Treatment includes wedge resection or lobectomy and administration of albendazole. Pre and postoperative chemotherapy with albendazole is recommended for 2 years after curative surgery.

Casoni’s test is a type I hypersensitivity reaction used in the diagnosis of hydatid disease. It is an intradermal test and a wheal response at the injection site occurring within 20 minutes is considered positive. 

Related Pearl: Skin tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Skin tests are performed by injecting parasitic antigen intradermally and observing the reaction. In immediate hypersensitivity reaction, wheal and flare response is seen within 30 minutes of injection, whereas in delayed type of hypersensitivity, erythema and induration are seen after 48 hours of injection.

The table below shows some of the important skin tests used in the diagnosis of parasitic infections.

questions.text: Monospot test is done in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Monospot test (Paul-Bunnell test) is done to identify heterophile antibody in a case of infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

questions.text:
Which of the following organisms would not give a similar positive reaction as shown in the image below?
  1. Streptococci
  2. Neisseria
  3. Staphylococci
  4. Vibrio
  5. Enterococci
questions.solution:
The given image shows a slide with a positive catalase test. Streptococci and enterococci are catalase-negative, and hence do not exhibit this reaction. 

Catalase test: When a microbial colony is placed in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), the catalase enzyme degrades H2O2 into H2O and O2. The liberated O2 is seen as gas bubbles.

Clinical application:

People with chronic granulomatous disease have recurrent attacks of infection with catalase-positive organisms.

The test is particularly useful in the differentiation of staphylococci (catalase-positive) from streptococci (catalase-negative).

Catalase positive organisms:

  • Staphylococcus
  • Pseudomonas
  • Vibrio    
  • Nocardia
  • Helicobacter
  • Campylobacter
  • Pasteurella
  • Legionella   
  • Enterobacteriaceae   
  • Listeria
  • Neisseria meningitidis   
  • Corynebacterium diphtheria
  • Yersinia

Catalase negative organisms:

  • Streptococci
  • Enterococci
  • Lactobacillus

questions.text: β 1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose all except?
questions.solution:
The β-1-3 glucan assay cannot be used to diagnose mucormycosis. This condition is usually diagnosed based on clinical features and culture.

The β-1-3 glucan assay detects the presence of (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG), an abundant cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi. It is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect beta-D-glucan by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes. 1,3 Beta D Glucan level of ≥80 pg/mL is considered a positive result.

Fungi that do not contain BDG in their cell walls include Cryptococcus neoformans, zygomycetes like rhizopus and mucor and Blastomyces dermatitidis. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic mycosis caused by zygomycetes, which do not contain (1-3)-β-d-glucan, and hence, the β 1-3 glucan assay cannot be used for its diagnosis.

questions.text: Xenodiagnosis is _______________

choices.text: The demonstration of a parasite in the vector following diagnostic infection
The demonstration of a parasite in the reservoir following diagnostic infection
The animal inoculation of a parasite for diagnostic observation
The animal inoculation of a parasite for serological observation

questions.solution:
Xenodiagnosis involves the diagnostic infection of a vector in which the parasite multiplies and can be demonstrated.

For example, in Trypanosoma cruzi, diagnosis may be established by letting the vector reduviid bug feed on suspected patients. After 4-5 weeks, live flagellate forms of Trypanosoma can be seen in the feces of the bugs. In Trichinella spirallis, biopsy bits are fed to laboratory rats, that are killed after a month to demonstrate larvae in the muscles.

Xenodiagnosis can be used in:

  • Wuchereria bancrofti
  • Trypanosoma cruzi
  • Trichinella spiralis

In the case of animal inoculation, Guinea pig or mice inoculation is done with blood, CSF, lymph node aspirate, or any other tissue material. This is a distinct modality, different from using the specific vector of the disease.

questions.text: Given below appearance is a feature of yeast phase of which of the following organism?
questions.solution:
Yeast phase of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis occurs in tissues and in cultures at 37oC as large, globose, or oval cells with multiple buds encircling the mother cells, giving a mariner’s wheel or pilot’s wheel appearance.

Paracoccidioidomycosis (PCM) is a systemic fungal infection caused by the dimorphic fungus Paracoccidioides brasiliensis and Paracoccidioides lutzii. This disease predominantly affects individuals in rural areas of Latin America, particularly Brazil, Argentina, Colombia, and Venezuela.

The fungus can then spread through the lymphatic system and bloodstream to other organs. The immune response to the infection involves both cellular and humoral immunity. Granuloma formation is a hallmark of chronic PCM, with macrophages, lymphocytes, and giant cells surrounding the yeast cells. The disease has an insidious onset with pulmonary involvement, leading to a chronic productive cough, dyspnea, and hemoptysis. Mucocutaneous lesions in the mouth, nose, and pharynx are common and may be painful and ulcerative.

Treatment is with amphotericin B or itraconazole.

questions.text: Name the parasite whose microfilaria have a sheath with no nuclei at the tail end.
questions.solution:
A sheathed microfilaria with a pointed tail free of nuclei is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti. 

Wuchereria bancrofti causes lymphatic filariasis and most cases are seen in India.

Clinical features include massive eosinophilia, hepatosplenomegaly, pulmonary manifestations like dry nocturnal cough, asthmatic wheezing, and dyspnea. It can also cause arthritis, glomerulonephritis, thrombophlebitis, etc. The classical features seen in lymphatic filariasis are usually absent.

Elephantiasis refers to the painful swelling of the legs and genital organs seen in late-stage disease.

Image showing elephantiasis-

Investigations:

Demonstration of the microfilaria in peripheral blood, chylous urine, hydrocele fluid, etc is done.  The specimen of choice is peripheral blood. Night blood samples between 10 pm and 4 am are preferred. This is because the microfilaria shows nocturnal periodicity.

DEC provocation test: In this test, a small dose of DEC is given 20-50 minutes before sample collection so that the microfilaria appears in the blood even during the daytime. 

The image below shows the life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti.

Related Pearl: Filarial worms and their morphology

Related Pearl: Important serological tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Serological tests are helpful for the detection and surveillance of many protozoal and helminthic infections.

These tests are basically of 2 types:

  • Tests for antigen detection
  • Tests for antibody detection

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the oncogenic mechanism of human papilloma virus ?

choices.text: E6 binds to RB protein and displaces E2F
E7 binds to RB protein and displaces E2F
Tax protein leading to polyclonal expansion of T cells
L1 protein leading to clonal expansion of T cells

questions.solution:
The true statement is that E7 protein of human papilloma virus (HPV) binds to the hypophosphorylated RB protein and displaces the E2F transcription factors, thereby promoting G1/S transition.

RB gene is a key negative regulator of the cell cycle at the G1/S transition. RB gene exists in an active hypophosphorylated state in resting cells and in an inactive hyperphosphorylated state in cells undergoing G1/S transition.

E7 protein from the high-risk types of HPV (such as HPV 16) binds to the hypophosphorylated RB through the same pocket that RB uses to bind and sequester the E2F transcription factors, thereby displacing the E2F which leads to the progression of the cell cycle and thus the proliferation of tumor cells. E7 proteins also inactivate the CDK inhibitors p21 and p27. E7 proteins from high-risk HPVs (types 16,18 and 31) also bind and presumably activate cyclins  A and E.

Oncogenic activities of protein E6:

The E6 protein binds to and helps in the degradation of p53 and stimulates the expression of telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT), which is the catalytic subunit of telomerase, thereby helping in the longevity of the cells. E6 from high-risk HPV types has a higher affinity for p53 than E6 from low-risk types. 

Other options :

Option C: HTLV-1 encodes the viral protein Tax, which leads to polyclonal expansion of T cells. It exhibits tropism for CD4+ T cells.

Option D: L1 major capsid protein is useful in the formulation of HPV vaccines.

questions.text: A patient presents with low-grade fever and small, grouped blisters on the lower lip, as shown in the given image. The causative agent belongs to which of the following subfamily of herpesviridae?
questions.solution:
Herpes simplex virus type 1 which belongs to the subfamily alpha viruses causes Herpes labialis (also known as cold sores) which is shown in the given image.

HSV type 1 (human herpes virus type 1 or HHY type 1) is isolated from lesions in and around the mouth and is transmitted by direct contact or droplet spread from cases or carrier. The most common site is the face- around the mouth, on the cheeks, chin, or on the forehead.

The Herpesviridae family is divided into 3 subfamilies:

  • Alpha herpes viruses
  • Betaherpes viruses
  • Gammaherpes viruses

 

Alpha viruses Beta viruses Gamma viruses
Short replicative cycle – 12-18 hours Replicative cycle - >24hours variable

Ex: HSV 1 and 2 , varicella zoster virus Ex: CMV Ex:EBV

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents to the medicine OPD with cough and hemoptysis. The sputum culture done on the culture media is shown below. What is the usual method of sterilization used for this medium?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Lowenstein-Jensen medium. The medium is sterilized by inspissation.

Inspissation is used for the sterilization of heat-labile culture media containing eggs or serum. This method of sterilization involves heating at 80–85 °C for 30 minutes on 3 consecutive days. Another medium for which this method is used is Loeffler's serum.

Lowenstein–Jensen medium is commonly used, egg-based, selective culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Loeffler's serum slope is an enriched medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Other Options:

Option B: Pasteurization - Milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes (the holder method) or at 72°C for 15–20 seconds (the flash process), followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower. 

Option C: Autoclaving is a method of sterilization by moist heat.

Option D: Hot air oven is a method of sterilization by dry heat.

Moist heat causes coagulation and denaturation of proteins, while dry heat causes oxidation and charring of proteins. Hence not preferred for egg-containing culture media like the Lowenstein-Jensen medium.

questions.text: Which of the following nematodes is oviparous?
questions.solution:
Ancylostoma is oviparous, which means the organisms lay eggs to reproduce.

Female nematodes are classified as follows:

  • Oviparous – Laying eggs
    • Unsegmented eggs: Ascaris, Trichuris
    • Segmented eggs: Ancylostoma, Necator
    • Eggs containing larva: Enterobius
  • Viviparous – Producing larvae
    • E.g., Trichinella, Wuchereria, Brugia, Dracunculus
  • Ovoviviparous – laying eggs containing fully formed larvae that hatch out immediately.
    • E.g., Strongyloides

Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) larvae enter the human host by skin penetration and undergo extraintestinal migration through the venous circulation to the lungs. They enter the alveoli, climb up to the bronchial tree and pharynx, and are swallowed. The larvae reach the small intestine and become adult worms.

Clinical manifestations include vitamin B12 deficiency and iron deficiency anemia, resulting from chronic occult intestinal blood loss. Dermatitis referred to as ground itch may occur when they penetrate human skin. Eosinophilic pneumonia can also be seen. The average blood loss of the host per worm per day is 0.2 mL with A. duodenale.

Oval, segmented hookworm eggs can be demonstrated in the feces by direct wet microscopy or concentration method. Stool culture by the Harada-Mori method demonstrates third-stage filariform larvae.

Infection with a zoonotic hookworm, especially Ancylostoma braziliense, can result in the subcutaneous migration of the larvae, causing cutaneous larva migrans.

The image given below shows cutaneous larva migrans.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Given is an image of hematoxylin and eosin stained of infected tissue. Which of the following is not true regarding the organism seen?

choices.text: Allergy following inhalation of airborne particles of the fungus
Colonization of tuberculous cavities in the lung
They proliferate in the walls of blood vessels cause infarction and necrosis of tissue.

questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of Aspergillus fumigatus.

It shows the characteristic feature of septate hyphae that branch at an acute angle of ~45 degrees.
This fungus causes

  • Invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients
  • Aspergillomas in pre-existing lung cavities
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis

Mucor, not Aspergillus, proliferate in blood vessel wall. 

Mucor fungi

They have irregular, broad, non-septate hyphae branching at wide angles.

They cause diseases mostly in ketoacidotic diabetic and/or neutropenic patients.  

Fungi proliferate in blood vessel walls, penetrate cribriform plate, and enter the brain.

They can cause rhinocerebral, frontal lobe abscess, and cavernous sinus thrombosis, which can manifest as headache; facial pain; black necrotic eschar on face; and, sometimes, cranial nerve involvement.

questions.text: A male sewer worker had an on-and-off fever for 2 weeks, followed by jaundice, and purple-blue spots on his skin. He developed hematuria and neck stiffness soon after that and was found to have deranged hepatic and renal parameters. He succumbed to death. A  hepatic tissue section is stained as shown below. What special stain has been used to visualize the specimen?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is consistent with a diagnosis of leptospirosis caused by Leptospires which are best visualized in tissue sections by staining using Levaditi's silver impregnation method.

Leptospirosis is caused by contact with the blood or urine of an infected organism in a contaminated water body. It is a type of zoonosis and can affect all mammalian species. Rats are well-known reservoirs. 

The clinical picture varies from mild disease to severe fatal disease, referred to as Weil's disease. Signs and symptoms of leptospirosis include fever, jaundice, meningismus, hemorrhage, and acute kidney injury. Faget sign (temperature pulse dissociation) is also seen.

A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis. In the acute phase of the disease, leptospires can be seen in blood in the first week of infection. This is done with darkfield microscopy or immunofluorescence.

Leptospires should be treated with IV penicillin. Ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, or doxycycline are alternatives for the treatment of severe leptospirosis.

Other options-

Option A: Albert's stain is used to demonstrate Corynebacteria with metachromatic granules. On staining with Albert stain, it shows delicate green bacilli with purple-blue metachromatic granules. 

Option C: Gomori’s methenamine silver stain is commonly used for staining fungal cell walls. It stains the fungal wall black.

Option D: Loeffler’s methylene blue is used to stain the granules of Corynebacteria a bluish-purple color.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department with oral and perioral lesions as seen in the image below. Similar lesions are also found on his palms and soles. What is the probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of hand, foot, and mouth disease, which is caused by Coxsackie A virus.

Hand, foot, and mouth disease:

It is a mild exanthematous fever that usually occurs in children, but may also occur in adults. It is characterized by papulovesicular rashes that involve the oral mucosa, palms, and soles.

The virus is shed in the stool and is transmitted by the feco-oral route. It is a self-limiting disease and subsides in 1-2 weeks. Treatment is symptomatic as the rash heals spontaneously.

Coxsackieviruses are enteroviruses and belong to the Picornaviridae family. They are classified into groups A and B. Group A viruses are classified into 24 types, and group B viruses are classified into 6 types.

Diseases caused by Coxsackie A viruses include -

  • Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) 
  • Herpangina - It is febrile vesicular pharyngitis. It is characterized by the presence of ulcerating small vesicles on the oral fauces, palate, or uvula, and the posterior pharyngeal wall.
  • Aseptic meningitis

Diseases caused by Coxsackie B viruses include -

  • Pleurodynia or Bornholm disease- It is viral myalgia defined by sudden severe lancinating pain, typically on one side of the chest. It is commonly associated with fever, malaise, and headaches. 
  • Myocarditis and pericarditis in the newborn.
  • Orchitis, juvenile diabetes

The following images show lesions affecting hands and feet: 

Other options:

Option B: Streptococcus causes impetigo. It is characterized by sores around the mouth and the nose and typically forms a honey-colored scab. It is more commonly seen in children. It is not associated with lesions on palms and soles.

The image given below shows impetigo.

Option C: Human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7) is a T-lymphotropic human herpes virus transmitted via saliva. It may cause roseola infantum/ sixth disease/ exanthem subitum in infants and young children. Roseola infantum is primarily caused by HHV-6.

The image given below shows typical rashes in an infant with exanthem subitum.

Option D: Poxvirus causes molluscum contagiosum in children and young adults. It is characterized by pink or pearly white wart-like nodules with central umbilication on the skin. 

The image given below shows molluscum contagiosum lesions.

questions.text: A middle-aged farmer, presented with fever, chills, and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. The smear prepared from the discharge was stained with Wayson stain and the finding is given below. Which bioterrorism category does the causative organism belong to?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever, chills, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, and a smear showing a characteristic safety pin appearance on Wayson stain is suggestive of bubonic plague caused by Yersinia pestis. It belongs to category A bioterrorism.

Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis. It is a gram-negative, non-motile, coccobacillus. The reservoirs of infection are wild rodents like field mice, gerbils, skunks, etc. The important vector of plague is rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis). Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague. 

Human plague mainly presents as:

  1. Bubonic plague - This is the most common type of disease. The patient develops a sudden fever, chills, headache, and painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes. 
  2. Pneumonic plague - Occurs as a complication of septic plague or bubonic plague and bacilli can be isolated from sputum as well.
  3. Septic plague - It occurs when the infection spreads to the blood.

Investigations include the demonstration of bacillus from the samples of blood, sputum, and buboes. Yersinia is a coccobacillus that exhibits bipolar staining with Wayson's stain. Culture and serology can also be done. Streptomycin is the drug of choice to treat plague, and it should be given intramuscularly in two doses (30 mg/kg). Other preventive measures include regular usage of rodenticides, proper application of effective insecticides, and disinfection. If a patient is suspected to have symptoms suggestive of plague, isolation is advised.

Bioterrorism is the deliberate release of an agent by attackers that causes one or more of a variety of different diseases. The agents of bioterrorism are classified into 3 categories:

  • Category A bioterrorism agents are those which are easily transmitted from one person to the other and are associated with high mortality rates and thus have the potential to cause major public health impacts. Examples include Bacillus anthracis, Clostridium botulinum, and Yersinia pestis.
  • Category B bioterrorism agents are those which are moderately easy to disseminate and are associated with moderate morbidity and low mortality rates. Examples include Coxiella burnetti and Brucella.
  • Category C bioterrorism agents are those which are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future due to ease of availability, high mortality and morbidity rates, and ease of production and dissemination. Examples include Nipah and Hanta viruses.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Clonorchis sinensis?

choices.text: Liver imaging shows dilated biliary tract
The second intermediate host is crab

questions.solution:
The second intermediate host of Clonorchis sinensis is fish (and not crab).

Clonorchis sinensis or Chinese liver fluke causes clonorchiasis.

  • Humans are infected by eating raw or undercooked fish containing the encysted larvae (metacercariae).

The immature flukes after excystation in the duodenum enter the biliary ducts and differentiate into adults.

The hermaphroditic adults produce eggs that are excreted in the faeces. Upon reaching freshwater the eggs are ingested by snails, which are the first intermediate hosts. The eggs hatch within the gut and differentiate first into larvae (rediae) and then into many free-swimming cercariae. Cercariae encyst to form metacercariae under the scales of certain freshwater fish (second intermediate host) which are then ingested by humans.

  • In humans, it infects the common bile duct and gallbladder. Liver imaging shows a dilated biliary tract.
  • It is a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma.

The life cycle of clonorchis sinensis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male from West Bengal presents with complaints of recurrent fever with chills for the past 3 months with progressive weakness and abdominal discomfort. On examination he has hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow aspiration finding is given in the image. Which of the following is the method of choice for the diagnosis of the disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical finding is suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis. The rapid dipstick test has become the mainstay in the serological diagnosis of Kala Azar and is the method of choice for the diagnosis of the disease.  

The image shows amastigotes located intracellularly in macrophages.

Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of genus Leishmania. Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disorder transmitted by the bite of an infected female phlebotomus sandfly in developing countries. The disease is transmitted by sandflies, which inoculate the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestations:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis, or kala-azar,
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis,
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, and
  • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis.

The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms:

  • The promastigote which develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and
  • The amastigote multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host.  

It lowers immunity, causes persistent fever, anemia, liver and spleen enlargement, and if left untreated, death may occur due to opportunistic infection.  

Diagnosis:

  • Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 Rapid diagnostic test and Kala-azar dipstick test strip.
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of amastigotes in smears of tissue aspirates is the gold standard for diagnosis of VL. Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear is also confirmatory.
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, indirect fluorescent antibody est.
  • Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: This test is based on the skin reaction. Induration of 5 mm or more is considered positive, usually positive 4-6 weeks after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis, valuable for distinguishing immune from non-immune subjects and endemicity.

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10 mg/kg IV is the first line of treatment in India.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are not true regarding the organism shown below?
  1. It can exhibit genetic reassortment.
  2. Vaccine against the organism is associated with an increased risk of intussusception.
  3. It is the most common agent to cause viral diarrhea in adults.
  4. Diagnosis can be made by antibody detection in stool specimens
  5. The main goal of treatment includes hydration and correction of fluid and electrolyte imbalance.
questions.solution:
The given image showing a cartwheel-shaped virus with 11 segmented RNA strands is suggestive of rotavirus. It is the most common identifiable viral cause of diarrhea in children below 5 years of age (Statement 3). Diagnosis can be made by rapid antigen detection of rotavirus in stool specimens (not antibody as in Statement 4).

The most common viral cause of diarrhea in adults is norovirus. Rotaviruses appear as cartwheel-shaped structures with short spokes radiating from them. 11 segments of double-stranded RNA constitute the genome. Influenza viruses have a linear, segmented, single-stranded RNA. Genetic reassortment occurs readily due to the presence of this segmented RNA (Statement 1).

Rotavirus is the most common identifiable viral cause of diarrhea in children below the age of 5 years and is most frequent between 6-24 months of age. The incubation period is 1-3 days. Most cases are asymptomatic or with mild symptoms like watery diarrhea, vomiting, low-grade fever, and temporary lactose intolerance. 

Infected individuals shed very high concentrations of the virus for many days in their stool and vomit. Diagnosis can be made by rapid antigen detection of rotavirus in stool specimens. Laboratory diagnosis depends on the demonstration of the virus in stool samples which is collected at an earlier course of illness. Antigen enzyme immunoassays (EIAs) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) are used to detect the virus in the stool. The polymerase chain reaction is the most sensitive detection method for genotyping of rotavirus nucleic acids from stool specimens.

Treatment is supportive including hydration, and correction of fluid and electrolyte imbalance (Statement 5). The main goals of treatment are avoiding and treating dehydration. Maintaining nutrition is a secondary goal. 

Live-attenuated, oral, monovalent, and multivalent vaccines are available for prophylaxis. e.g. Rotateq, Rotarix, Rotasiil, and Rotavac. The rotavirus vaccine is associated with a potential risk of intussusception (Statement 2). Rotavac (monovalent liquid frozen) vaccine is administered in 3 oral doses, 4 weeks apart at 6, 10, and 14 weeks. Because of this risk, the rotavirus vaccine is not a part of catch-up immunization programs.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used for the estimation of viable bacterial count in a suspension?
questions.solution:
The culture method used for the estimation of viable bacterial count in a suspension is pour plate culture.

Pour plate culture is prepared by adding appropriate dilutions of the inoculum (of 1 ml) to the molten (40-45°C) agar, which is mixed and poured into sterile Petri dishes. After incubation, colonies are seen to be distributed throughout the depth of the medium. Colony counters can then be used for determining the exact colony count.

Other methods used in bacterial culture:

  • Lawn culture/carpet culture: It is used for bacteriophage typing and antibiotic sensitivity testing. It is prepared by flooding the surface of the plate with a liquid culture.
  • Streak culture: It is routinely used for isolation of bacteria in pure culture from clinical specimens. It is prepared by picking the specimen using platinum loops or straight wires and transferring it onto a well-dried plate. The inoculum is then distributed thinly over the plate by streaking it with the loop in a series of parallel lines, in different segments of the plate.
  • Liquid culture: These are preferred for inocula containing antibiotics and other inhibitory substances. It is prepared by inoculating liquid cultures in tubes, bottles, or flasks by touching with a charged loop, pipettes or syringe.

questions.text: The 5th disease is the name given to:
questions.solution:
Erythema infectiosum is also known as the 5th disease.

Erythema infectiosum is caused by parvovirus B19. Parvovirus-B19 is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus. The incubation period after infection is typically around 4-14 days.

It evolves in three phases:

  • The first phase - sudden onset diffuse and macular, asymptomatic erythema of the cheeks (slapped cheek). Prodromal symptoms may occur. During the rash period, the patient is generally non-infectious.

The image given below shows the classical slapped cheek appearance of erythema infectiosum caused by parvovirus B19.

  • The second phase -  begins after 1–4 days, with discrete erythematous macules and papules on the proximal extremities and later the trunk.

The image given below shows a lacy or reticular pattern of rash involving the proximal extremities and trunk seen in the 5th disease.

  • Third phase - The recurring stage, the eruption is significantly reduced or invisible, only to recur after the patient is exposed to heat or sunlight, or in response to crying or exercise.

Only about 7% of children with erythema infectiosum have arthralgias, whereas 80% of adults who have joint involvement in the hands and knees may be involved in mimicking rheumatoid arthritis, and arthropathy.

Parvovirus B-19 infection may have several presentations like:

  • Transient aplastic crisis - It may be seen in patients with underlying chronic hemolytic anemia like sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, and RBC enzyme deficiencies like pyruvate kinase deficiency. Patients with aplastic crisis appear ill with fever, malaise, and pale with tachycardia and tachypnea due to profound anemia. The rash may or may not be present. Children with sickle-cell disease may also develop vaso-occlusive crises.
  • Pure red cell aplasia - Persistent B19V infection that results in pure red cell aplasia has been reported in many immunosuppressed patients, including patients with congenital immunodeficiency, AIDS, and lymphoproliferative disorders and transplant recipients.
  • Primary maternal infection is associated with non-immune fetal hydrops and intrauterine fetal demise

It is a clinical diagnosis that does not require investigations usually. However, in the case of pregnant women or with other manifestations an IgM ELISA or PCR assay may be done. It is self-limited and resolves on its own.

questions.text: A patient presented with bull neck edema and a pseudomembrane on the tonsils. Which of the following stains is used to demonstrate volutin granules of this organism?
questions.solution:
Presence of bull neck edema and pseudomembrane on tonsils points towards the diagnosis of diphtheria. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Albert stain is one of three stains that can be used to demonstrate the volutin granules (metachromatic/Babes-Ernst granules) of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. 

The two other stains used for this purpose are Neisser’s stain and Ponder’s stain. The bacilli are usually arranged in pairs or palisades or small groups, at various angles to each other, resembling the letters V or L. This has been called the Chinese letter or cuneiform arrangement.

questions.text:
Match the following inclusion bodies with the respective organisms.
1. Lipschutz inclusions a. Chlamydia psittaci 
2. Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies (LCL bodies) b. Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes A, B, Ba, and C
3. Halberstaedter-Prowazek bodies c. Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes L1, L2, and L3
4. Henderson-Patterson bodies d. Herpes virus
  e. Molluscum contagiosum
questions.solution:
The correct match is as follows:

1.Lipschutz inclusions d. Herpes virus
2. Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies (LCL bodies) a. Chlamydia psittaci
3. Halberstaedter-Prowazek bodies b. Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes A, B, Ba, and C
4. Henderson-Patterson bodies e. Molluscum contagiosum

Inclusion bodies are structures with distinct sizes and shapes that are seen in infected cells under light microscopy. 

Lipschutz or Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies are found in Herpes viruses.

 

Halberstaedter-Prowazek (HP) bodies are demonstrated in conjunctival scrapings of patients with trachoma, caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes A, B, Ba, and C. They stain well with iodine as they contain glycogen. 

Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies are inclusion bodies of Chlamydia psittaci seen in infected cells including alveolar macrophages from patients suffering from psittacosis. They are present in cell cultures also. Distinguishing features from inclusion bodies of C. trachomatis are that they are more diffuse and irregular and are not stained by iodine.

The Miyagawa granulocorpuscles/ elementary bodies  are inclusion bodies seen in lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). They are intracytoplasmic microcolonies of Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes L1, L2, and L3, seen on microscopy of the aspirated material from the buboes. 

Molluscum contagiosum shows the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies called Henderson-Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies (Shown in the image below).

questions.text: A microbiology resident is using the Lowenstein-Jensen medium as a selective medium for the culture of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The presence of which of the following components makes it a selective medium?
questions.solution:
The presence of malachite green makes Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium a selective medium by inhibiting other bacteria. 

Contents of LJ medium:

  1. Egg: Provides fatty acids and protein required for metabolism.
  2. Malachite green: prevents the growth of contaminants.
  3. Mineral salt solution: Acts as a buffer.
  4. Glycerol: Source of carbon, favors the growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. Bovis.
  5. L-asparagine: Source of Nitrogen.  

Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are dry, rough, raised, and irregular with a wrinkled surface. They are creamy white or buff-colored, tenacious, and difficult to emulsify (rough, tough, buff). 

Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

  • Solid culture media: Lowenstein–Jensen (A commonly used, egg-based, selective media).
  • Liquid culture media: Dubos' media, Middle Brook’s media. Virulent strains tend to form long serpentine cords in liquid media, while avirulent strains grow in a more dispersed manner.
  • Automated Culture Media: 
    • BACTEC 460: Uses radioisotopes
    • BacT/ALERT: A colorimetric method
    • BACTEC MGIT: A fluorometric detection method.

questions.text: A male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of fever, joint pain, and urticarial rash. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. The microscopy image of the stool sample is given below. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing a non-operculated egg with a lateral spine are suggestive of Katayama fever caused by Schistosoma mansoni. Praziquantel is the drug of choice for the condition.

Katayama fever is an immune complex-mediated disease caused by antibodies against high worm load and egg antigen. This acute illness presents with high-grade fever, rash, arthralgia, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and eosinophilia. 

Adult worms of S. mansoni live in the inferior mesenteric vein and their infective form is fork-tailed cercaria. Following skin penetration by cercariae, a pruritic rash termed cercarial dermatitis or swimmers itch develops locally which is self-limiting.

After 4-8 weeks of the cercarial invasion, high worm load, and egg antigen stimuli lead to the formation of immune complexes, which results in a serum sickness-like illness termed Katayama fever.

When eggs get deposited in the small intestine, patients develop abdominal pain and dysentery for a long time called intestinal bilharziasis. The deposition of the eggs in the intestinal wall leads to microabscesses, granulomas, hyperplasia, and fibrosis. 

The drug of choice is praziquantel 40 mg/kg single oral dose. Oxamniquine 15 mg/kg single oral dose is also an effective dose. It distorts the tegument of the male worm and makes the worm more susceptible to the lethal action of the immune system.

The life cycle of schistosomes is represented below:

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents with a history of purulent urethral discharge and painful micturition for the past 2 days. Why is the following medium used to elicit the growth of the suspected pathogenic organism in this patient?

choices.text: Growth of other commensals is suppressed

questions.solution:
Thayer-Martin medium is shown in the above image, and it is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae because the antimicrobials present in it suppress the growth of other commensal organisms.

Gonorrhea in males most commonly manifests as acute urethritis - mucopurulent urethral discharge and burning micturition, as mentioned in the given clinical scenario. 

Contents of Thayer-Martin medium includes

  • Vancomycin: to inhibit most gram-positive bacteria
  • Colistin (Polymyxin E): to inhibit most gram-negative bacteria other than Neisseria
  • Nystatin or anisomycin: to inhibit yeast

Note: Contents of Modified Thayer-Martin medium are same as those of Thayer-Martin medium, except that the former contains an additional antibiotic trimethoprim to inhibit proteus.

Since N. gonorrhoeae, N. meningitidis, and N. lactamica are colistin-resistant they can be grown on these selective media.

Gonorrhea in males: 

  • The disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis.
  • Chronic urethritis may result in stricture formation.
  • The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscess and multiple discharging sinuses (water can perineum).

Gonorrhea in females: 

  • The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes.
  • The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because of the stratified squamous epithelium. It is resistant to infection by the cocci, and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions.
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may result in sterility.
  • Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation termed Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

Other options:

Option A- Enrichment media are liquid media, which allow for the growth of certain organisms and inhibit the growth of others (natural flora). Substances having a stimulating effect on bacteria, which is to be grown, or an inhibitory effect on those to be suppressed are used in this medium. Examples include

  • Tetrathionate broth where tetrathionate allows typhoid-paratyphoid bacilli to grow and inhibits coliforms.
  • Selenite F broth for dysentery-causing bacteria 

Option C - McLeod medium is an indicator medium that contains potassium tellurite. Tellurite is reduced to metallic tellurium by Corynebacterium diphtheriae to produce black colonies.

Option D - Enriched medium: When a basal medium is added with additional nutrients such as blood, serum, or egg, it is called enriched medium. e.g. Lowenstein-Jensen medium is an inspissated selective egg medium containing fresh egg or egg yolk used for the primary isolation of Mycobacterium species.

questions.text: Which of the following toxins is incorrectly matched with their mechanism of action?

choices.text: Botulinum toxin - Presynaptic inhibition of acetylcholine release
ST(heat-stable) toxin of Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) - Acts by  increasing cAMP
Tetanospasmin - Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release

questions.solution:
ST toxin(heat-stable toxin) of Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) acts by increasing cGMP levels, not cAMP levels.

Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) is the most common organism causing traveler’s diarrhea. It produces the following toxins:

  • LT (heat-labile toxin)- acts by ↑cAMP
  • ST (heat-stable toxin)- two types of ST are known, ST-A (ST-I) and ST-B (ST-II)
    • ST-A is soluble in methanol and acts by ↑ cGMP in the intestine. 
    • ST-B is insoluble in methanol, and the mode of action is not known.

Other Options:

Option A: Shiga toxin or verotoxin is an exotoxin produced by Shigella species. The mechanism of action of exotoxin is the inhibition of 60S ribosome. It consists of two subunits A and B. The B subunit binds to globotriaosylceramide receptors on the target cell, and then, the A subunit gets internalized. The A subunit leads to inhibition of 60S ribosome, leading to shut down of protein synthesis.

Option B: Botulinum toxin produced by Clostridium botulinum, acts by presynaptic inhibition of acetylcholine release . Botulinum toxin causes proteolysis of snare proteins. These are required for the exocytosis of acetylcholine vesicles. Thus, it leads to presynaptic inhibition of neuronal transmission. Blocking of acetylcholine release from nerve terminal is permanent and recovery occurs only by sprouting of new nerve

The image given below shows the site of action of botulinum toxin.

Option D: Tetanospasmin produced by Clostridium tetani acts by causing presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release (inhibitory neurotransmitters). This leads to increased release of acetylcholine, thereby leading to the development of spastic paralysis.

The image below depicts the mechanism of action of tetanus toxin.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: A patient died due to encephalitis. A postmortem biopsy of the brain tissue is shown below. This finding is characteristic of infection caused by:
questions.solution:
The finding in the image shows Negri bodies, which is characteristic of the infection caused by the rabies virus.

Negri bodies are pathognomonic of rabies virus infection. These are spherical-shaped cytoplasmic inclusion bodies. They contain eosinophilic matrix, basophilic granules, and viral antigens. 

Rabies is a fatal infection of the central nervous system transmitted by the bite of a rabid animal. It is caused by rhabdoviruses. These viruses are enveloped, rod or bullet shaped, and contain single-stranded RNA.

Clinical features of rabies can be categorized into three phases: prodromal, encephalitic phase, and coma. Prodromal phase is characterised by malaise, anorexia, headache, and irritability. This is followed by the encephalitic stage characterized by abnormal behavior and seizures. They develop hydrophobia. Attempts to drink liquids cause painful spasms of the pharynx and larynx, producing a choking sensation. Therefore, the patients develop a phobia of even the sight or sound of water. Finally, seizures, coma, and death occur.

Laboratory diagnosis can be done on a postmortem or antemortem basis. Postmortem diagnosis is done by the demonstration of Negri bodies. These bodies are common in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. Antemortem diagnosis is done from corneal scrapings, saliva, or skin biopsy. Demonstration of the virus is done using direct immunofluorescence. 

Other methods used in the diagnosis are intracerebral inoculation in the mice, tissue culture, ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay), and PCR (polymerase chain reaction).

questions.text: During a microbiology experiment, the gene for diphtheria toxin from Corynebacterium diphtheriae is carried on corynebacteriophages, and the toxin is produced only by the bacteria that are lysogenized by the phages. Which of the following methods of horizontal gene transfer is outlined in the above example?
questions.solution:
The transfer of genes for diphtheria toxin on a corynebacteriophage occurs by transduction.

Transduction can be defined as the transfer of a portion of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage. This type of horizontal gene transfer may occur by two mechanisms:

  • Lytic cycle - In the lytic cycle, also known as the virulent cycle, a large number of progeny phages build up inside the host bacterium; eventually, the host cell ruptures, releasing the bacteriophages. Some of the bacteriophages will now contain bacterial DNA, which can then be transferred to other bacteria.
  • Lysogenic cycle - In the temperate or non-lytic cycle, the host bacterium is not lysed. Rather, the phage DNA becomes integrated with the bacterial chromosome. This phage DNA multiplies with the host cell and is transferred to daughter cells. 

Option A - Conjugation is the method of gene transfer in bacteria that involves physical contact by a male or donor bacterium with a female or recipient bacterium through an extracellular protein extrusion or appendage called the sex pili. The genetic material that is transferred is usually derived from plasmids. The bacteria that possess the ability to form the sex pili contain the F+ plasmid and are designated as F+. The F+ bacteria can transfer a single strand of the F+ plasmid DNA to F- bacteria via the sex pili. 

Option C - Transformation is the direct uptake of naked DNA by the bacterial cell from the environment. Several bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria undergo transformation. 

Option D - Transposition is a process of gene transfer that involves special segments of DNA called transposons (jumping genes).

questions.text: Which of the following is a type I hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Casoni’s test is a type I hypersensitivity reaction used in the diagnosis of hydatid disease.

  • It involves the intradermal injection of 0.25 ml of sterilized fluid from hydatid cysts/human cyst and sterilized by Seitz filtration on the forearm and an equal volume of saline injected on the other forearm.
  • Observations are made for next 30 mins and after 1 to 2 days.
  • A wheal response occurring at the injection site within 20 minutes is considered positive.

Cell-mediated or type IV type of hypersensitivity reaction is a delayed hypersensitivity.

  • In the tuberculin skin test, the indurated skin rash is caused by CD4-positive helper T cells and macrophages that are attracted to the injection site.
  • The Frei test is done to identify lymphogranuloma venereum. Antigen made from sterile pus aspirated from previously unruptured abscesses produced a reaction in patients with lymphogranuloma inguinale when injected intradermally.
  • Montenegro test is a delayed hypersensitivity test for cutaneous leishmaniasis.

questions.text:
Which of the following are examples of dimorphic fungi?
  1. Cryptococcus neoformans
  2. Sporothrix schenckii
  3. Candida albicans
  4. Aspergillus fumigatus
  5. Histoplasma capsulatum
questions.solution:
Among the given organisms, Sporothrix schenckii and Histoplasma capsulatum are examples of dimorphic fungi.

Dimorphic fungi exist in the yeast form in body tissues and cultures maintained at 37°C, and in the filamentous mold form in cultures at room temperature (25°C).

Some common examples of dimorphic fungi are:

  • Blastomyces dermatitidis
  • Coccidioides immitis
  • Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
  • Penicilliosis marneffei
  • Sporothrix schenckii
  • Histoplasma capsulatum

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that causes cryptococcosis. It is an oval, budding yeast with a prominent polysaccharide capsule, which is very apparent in India ink staining. It forms smooth, mucoid, cream-colored colonies on Sabouraud agar.

Candida albicans is an opportunistic pathogen that causes candidiasis. It is a yeast when part of the normal flora of mucous membranes but forms pseudohyphae and hyphae when it invades tissue. They are not dimorphic. It forms germ tubes when incubated at 37 degrees Celsius. It is gram-positive and forms colonies of yeasts on Sabouraud's agar.

Aspergillus fumigatus is an opportunistic pathogen that causes aspergillosis. It is a non-dimorphic mold with septate hyphae with an acute angle branching. It forms characteristic mycelium when cultured on Sabouraud’s agar.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old patient presents with a high-grade fever with chills, headache, fatigue, and weakness for the past 6 days. Laboratory investigations reveal low hemoglobin level, reticulocytosis, and increased unconjugated bilirubin level. The microscopic examination of the thin blood smear is given below. Which of the following statements are correct regarding this disease?

1. It is transmitted by ixodid tick.

2. Sporozoites are the infective form for humans.

3. Man is the definitive host.

4. The ring forms are rarely seen.

5. Schizonts and gametocytes are absent.
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the microscopic image showing tetrads arranged in Maltese cross formation, which is pathognomonic of babesiosis. The correct statements regarding babesiosis are 1, 2, and 5.

Babesia:

Babesia, a genus of protozoan organisms that includes Babesia microti and Babesia duncani, are responsible for babesiosis. Ixodid ticks are the definitive host. Man is an intermediate host. Sporozoites are the infective form for humans.

The mode of infection is through a tick bite. Occasionally it can also be through blood transfusion.

The majority of the clinical symptoms are predominantly caused by hemolysis of the infected erythrocytes. The illness develops 1-6 weeks after the tick bite. It might be a mild, self-limiting, asymptomatic, or severe sickness that resembles malaria.
Malaise, exhaustion, high-grade fever (38°C to 40.6°C) with chills and sweating, myalgia, arthralgia, a dry cough, and anorexia are symptoms of acute illness.

Complications of acute babesiosis include renal failure, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and congestive cardiac failure (CCF).

Diagnosis is made by the examination of blood films stained with Leishman or Giemsa stain.

  • Babesia appears as intraerythrocytic pyriform, or ring form simulating Plasmodium falciparum
  • The ring forms are the most common and lack the central hemozoin deposit.
  • Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads (Maltese crosses), which are pathognomonic of B. microti or B. duncani.

Treatment of B. microti infection

  • Mild infection is treated with atovaquone along with azithromycin
  • Severe infections are treated with azithromycin along with atovaquone or clindamycin along with quinine
  • Exchange transfusion is required in patients with high-grade parasitemia (≥10%), severe anemia, and pulmonary, hepatic, or renal compromise.

Other Babesia infections are treated with a combination of clindamycin and quinine.
