questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever and cough. On blood culture, the causative organism was found to be Haemophilus influenzae. Which of the following is not true regarding the bacteria?

choices.text: It requires growth factors V and X
It is a spore forming bacillus

questions.solution:
Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus that is non-motile and non-spore-forming. 

When present in the sputum, H. influenzae appears as a coccobacillus, but in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), it appears as a filamentous bacillus. 

H. influenzae requires growth factors V and X (Option A) that are present in the blood.

  • Factor V  is a nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), a coenzyme, and is heat labile.
  • Factor X is hemin. It is required for cytochrome synthesis and the function of enzymes like catalase and peroxidase. It is heat stable.

When H. influenzae is cultured on the same plate as Staphylococcus aureus. The closer the colonies of H. influenzae are to S. aureus, the larger the growth. This is termed satellitism (Option B). This occurs because factor V is released by the hemolytic action of S. aureus. 

The image below shows satellitism.

Hemophilus influenzae has a capsular polysaccharide (Option D) which is a major antigenic determinant. Capsular typing is done to identify strains. Importantly, the type b capsular polysaccharide has a polyribosyl ribitol phosphate antigen (PRP). PRP is targeted during immunization. 

H. influenzae can cause meningitis, laryngo-epiglottitis, pneumonia, bronchitis, and suppurative lesions like arthritis, endocarditis, and pericarditis. 

Cefotaxime or ceftazidime is the drug of choice for the treatment of Haemophilus meningitis. H.influenzae produces beta-lactamase, hence resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics like ampicillin.

H. influenza can be prevented by immunization with the Hib vaccine. The vaccine is produced based on the type b capsular polysaccharide. The capsule is composed of polyribosyl ribitol phosphate which can induce IgG, IgM, and IgA antibodies. Those that do not have a capsule are not candidates for vaccine prevention. Apart from H. influenza type b, the non-typeable strains are those that produce the clinical infections presently.

questions.text: A 44-year-old HIV patient presents with a non-productive cough and progressively worsening breathing difficulty. Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates along with a pneumatocele. Microscopic examination of the bronchoalveolar lavage shows the following. What is the special stain used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the staining showing the black-colored stained cysts, resembling the crushed ping pong balls, are suggestive of Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). It is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii. The stain used for staining the causative organism is Gomori’s methenamine silver stain.

Patients with PCP generally present with fever and cough that is usually non-productive. Finding on chest x-ray is either a normal film if the disease is suspected early, or diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The classic finding of dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.

Treatment: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and pentamidine isethionate

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presented to the clinic with fever, malaise, and headache. On examination, a lesion is seen over his right arm as shown in the below image. Later the patient developed sepsis. On Gram staining from cultures, bamboo stick appearance was seen. Which of the following reactions is characteristic of this bacilli?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a necrotic ulcer with a characteristic black eschar are suggestive of cutaneous anthrax with septicemia signs caused by Bacillus anthracis. The characteristic reaction shown by these bacilli is M'Fadyean’s reaction.

When blood films containing anthrax bacilli are stained with polychrome methylene blue for a few seconds and examined under the microscope, amorphous purplish material is noticed around the bacilli which shows the capsular material. This is called M'Fadyean’s reaction.

Cutaneous anthrax is usually acquired by the entry of spores through injured skin. The lesion starts as a papule and becomes vesicular. Several satellite lesions are seen around a central necrotic lesion which is covered by a black eschar. This lesion is called a malignant pustule. Cutaneous anthrax generally resolves spontaneously.

On microscopy, they appear as gram-positive rods. Bacilli are arranged end to end in long chains. The ends of the bacilli are truncated or often concave and somewhat swollen so that a chain of bacilli presents a bamboo stick appearance.

The organisms produce nonhemolytic grey-to-white, tenacious colonies with a rough texture and a ground-glass appearance in blood agar. Comma-shaped outgrowths (Medusa head, curled hair) may project from the colony.

Other options:

Option A - Naegler's reaction is a useful test for the rapid detection of Clostridium perfringens.

Option B - The reverse CAMP test is used to identify Clostridium perfringens.

Option D - Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon is demonstrated by sporotrichosis, pityrosporum folliculitis, zygomycosis, candidiasis, aspergillosis, and blastomycosis. It is also seen in bacterial infections such as botryomycosis, nocardiosis, and actinomycosis, and parasitic conditions include orbital pythiosis, strongyloidiasis, schistosomiasis, and cutaneous larva migrans.

questions.text: The egg shown in the given image is recovered from the perianal region using the scotch tape technique. Identify the parasite.
questions.solution:
The egg shown in the given image is that of Enterobius vermicularis.

The eggs of E. vermicularis are plano-convex in shape, have a double-layered outer shell, and are approximately 50–60 μm in length. Infectious larvae, which are tadpole-shaped, are often visible inside the egg. Unlike those of other intestinal nematodes, these eggs are not found in the stools. The female worm lays eggs in the perianal region.

The eggs are recovered using the scotch tape technique in the morning before a bowel movement. Transparent scotch tape is applied directly to the perianal area and then placed on a microscope slide for examination.

Other options: 

Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are large, broadly oval, with thick mammillated shell, and are typically stained golden brown with bile.

Ancylostoma duodenale eggs are oval and thin-shelled and contain a clearly visible four to eight-cell stage embryo. There is a characteristic clear space between the shell and the developing embryo.

Strongyloides stercoralis eggs hatch within the mucosa of the small intestine forming rhabditiform larvae. These larvae are passed in the stools, not the eggs.

questions.text: A young woman presents with fever, severe myalgia and arthralgia, and pain behind the eyes for 3 days. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and leucopenia. NS-1 antigen has been detected in her blood sample. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this disease?

choices.text: The causative agent belongs to orthomyxoviridae
It is transmitted by Aedes aegypti

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of dengue and dengue viruses are members of the flaviviridae family, not orthomyxoviridae.

Dengue viruses are enveloped viruses that are transmitted from person to person by Aedes aegypti (tiger mosquitoes). 

Dengue is an acute febrile illness. The patient presents with sudden-onset fever, retro-orbital pain, muscle and joint pains, and a rash. Dengue fever is sometimes referred to as ‘break bone fever’ due to associated severe muscle and joint pain. The initial rash in dengue may appear as flushing erythema of the face in the first 2 days of symptoms. A second rash occurs 3-6 days after the onset of fever and appears maculopapular or morbilliform. Sometimes, lesions may coalesce and appear as white islands in a red sea due to generalized erythema with petechiae and islands of sparing. As the disease progress, it can be associated with leukopenia and thrombocytopenia.

Suspected cases of dengue are confirmed by the presence of NS-1 antigen or IgM antibodies.

The condition is self-limiting and the treatment of dengue is supportive management, with hydration and paracetamol for fever. If there is severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000) then platelets should be transfused. 

The image below shows erythema with petechiae in a patient with dengue fever showing white islands in a red sea appearance.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the emergency department with a fever and persistent cough. On examination, chest retractions and tachypnea were noted and expiratory wheezes were heard over both lungs. The culture of the nasopharyngeal swab showed characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation. Which of the following is most likely to have caused this infection?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture, along with the culture showing characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation, is characteristic of bronchiolitis, which is most likely to be caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).

RSV is responsible for more than half of the cases of bronchiolitis in infants less than 1 year of age. Viral transmission is by close contact, droplet transmission, and through contaminated fingers and fomites.

The disease may begin as febrile illness, with cough and wheezing. RSV causes a broad range of respiratory illnesses. Outbreaks are commonly seen in pediatric wards, nurseries, and daycare centers. RSV also causes otitis media in children. 

Samples are collected by nasopharyngeal swabs and nasal washings. They are inoculated in cell culture (HeLa or Hep-2) immediately after collection. In cultured cells, RSV shows characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation. Cytopathic effects usually appear after 10 days of culture.   

The image given below shows giant cells and syncytial formation seen in RSV infection.

Continuous administration of ribavirin is found beneficial for hospitalized patients.

Other options:

Option A: Rhinovirus attaches to receptors on nasal ciliated epithelial cells, enters and replicates within them, spreading to other cells and causing local inflammation and the common cold.

Option B: Adenovirus types 3 and 7 cause pneumonia in adults. In infants and young children, type 7 causes serious and fatal pneumonia.

Option C: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) causes cytomegalic inclusion disease that occurs in infants born to mothers who develop primary CMV infection during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman from a tribal area presented with fever, chills, malaise, fatigue, and headache for the past 3 days. The peripheral blood smear examination is as shown in the image. Which of the following is false regarding the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocytes, which are binucleate resembling stereo headphones in appearance, are characteristic of P. falciparum malaria. Hypnozoites are absent in P. falciparum infection.

Malaria is a parasitic infection caused by the Plasmodium species transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito. It is characterized by many nonspecific symptoms, including but not limited to tachycardia, tachypnea, chills, malaise, fatigue, diaphoresis (sweating), and headache. The fever of malaria is characterized by periodicity depending on the infective Plasmodium species. The fever returns every other day for Plasmodium vivax, Plasmodium ovale, and Plasmodium falciparum, and every three days for P. malariae. 

The peripheral smear finding of P. falciparum malaria are:

  • Normal size RBCs
  • Multiple ring form
  • Accole form
  • Absent schizont
  • Banana shaped gametocytes
  • Maurer's dots

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy from Tamil Nadu was rushed to the emergency department with a headache, fever, and blurred vision, followed shortly by unresponsiveness to verbal commands. He is suspected to have mosquito-borne viral encephalitis. Which of the following is not true about the likely causative agent?
  1. It is transmitted by Culex vishnui
  2. Man acts as the reservoir
  3. Herons act as an amplifier host
  4. Majority of the infections by this agent are asymptomatic
  5. SA-14-14-2 vaccine is approved for protection against the agent in India.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of mosquito borne viral encephalitis in a patient from an endemic region (Tamil Nadu) is suggestive of Japanese encephalitis (JE). Humans are the dead-end hosts for the virus (Statement 2). Herons act as reservoir hosts (Statement 3), and pigs act as the amplifier hosts.

JE follows bird-arthropod-human transmission. The disease is transmitted by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui, which are common in India (Statement 1). Humans are the dead-end hosts, pigs are the amplifier hosts, and Ardeid birds like herons and egrets are reservoir hosts. (Ardeid are medium to large wading birds found mostly in coastal areas. The herons are long-legged freshwater and coastal birds in the family Ardeidae.)

It is characterized by sudden onset of fever and vomiting, which later progresses to encephalitis. Signs of encephalitis such as convulsions, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium appear after 1-6 days. Up to 50% of survivors may have neurological or psychiatric sequelae. Infection during first or the second trimester may even result in fetal mortality. It is the leading cause of childhood neurological viral infection in India. It was first reported in Vellore in India and continues to be active in states of Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, and other states, causing illness mainly in children. An important point of note is that the majority of the infections are in fact asymptomatic and >300-500+ asymptomatic infections occur for every symptomatic case of JE(Statement 4). 

No specific treatments have been found to benefit patients with JE, but hospitalization for supportive care and close observation is generally required. Treatment is symptomatic. Rest, fluids, and the use of pain relievers and medication to reduce fever may relieve some symptoms. The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from human dwellings, and vaccinating pigs.

A live attenuated SA-14-14-2 vaccine is approved for use in India (Statement 5). JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunization Schedule.
